Award.AwardTitle: Identifying and Addressing Factors that Contribute to Michigan's STEM Educator Shortage

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
In this Robert Noyce Teacher Scholarship Program Capacity Building project, Siena Heights University (SHU) will work to identify and address the causes of Southeast Michigan's STEM educator shortage. Based on that knowledge the principal investigators (PIs) will start building a pipeline of highly-qualified secondary STEM educators and share the results with partners in secondary and higher education throughout the region. Over the funding period, the project team will develop action plans for increasing retention and graduation rates in SHU's secondary education program and Michigan Test for Teacher Certification (MTTC) pass rates for students who graduate. The PIs intend to use the plans as the basis of a future Noyce Scholarships and Stipends Track 1 proposal.

SHU will conduct the project in partnership with Jackson College, a local two-year college, and nearby high-need education agencies, Adrian, Hudson, Madison, and Morenci Public Schools. Faculty in SHU's Division of Education and Division of Computing, Mathematics, and Sciences will assess institutional and community needs and develop collaborative partnerships to increase the number of high school, transfer, and SHU undergraduates who pursue careers in secondary STEM education. The project team will work on ways to recruit more biology and chemistry students into the secondary education certification program (regionally, the disciplines of highest need), identify barriers to student retention in these disciplines, and establish action plans to increase retention, graduation, and MTTC pass rates. Intended outcomes of the work also include the establishment of pathways for high school and community college transfer students to pursue secondary STEM teaching careers. Furthermore, the PIs aim to assess and develop SHU's secondary STEM education curriculum, advising, and academic support systems. The project team will study the benefits of web-based, on-demand learning modules, integrated supplemental instruction in biology and chemistry and develop a 2 + 3 certification pathway for two-year college students. Results from this study will add to the knowledge base of effective strategies for guiding students into successful careers as secondary STEM educators.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
To adress the shortage of secondary STEM education majors at Siena Heights University, and more broadly to increase the number of STEM teachers in SE Michigan, we developed a seamless 2 + 3-year bachelors degree program in secondary STEM education as a joint venture with a 2-yr community college. Students complete the first two years of the secondary STEM education curriculum at Jackson College and then transfer all of those credits to Siena Heights University and complete their bachelors degree and certification pathways over the next three years. In addition, new processes related to academic advising have been established to (1) educate science majors who are contemplating changing majors about careers in teaching, and (2) advise students who have not yet chosen a major about careers in STEM education and connect them with education faculty who can further provide support. We also added a career day to give our science majors the opportunity to meet secondary education teachers and explore a career in STEM teaching with them. 

In addition to working on ways to enhance recruitment into our teacher education programs, we also focused on improving retention and academic success for  studnets who have chosen the secondary education pathway already. Accordingly, SHU science faculty have initiated the planning phase for a major overhaul of our curriculum to bring it into better allignment with the Michigan Test for Teacher Certification (MTTC)  in Chemistry , Biology, and Mathematics. Furhthermore, the curriculum changes are also being informed by an analysis of the student performance on the MTTC tests in Biology & Chemistry and mathematics, especially related to performance in specific subareas. 

We also identified science courses with the lowest rates of student success and targeted them for the additiona of a proactive student support model, Supplemental Instruction.  Science faculty were trained at the International Center for Supplemental Instruction at the University of Missouri Kansas City. Students who performed well in the courses in question were hired as supplemental instructors and were provided training and support by the science faculty.  SI student leaders held weekly sessions during the semester in biology and chemistry courses.  Students who attended the SI sessions reported an improved understanding of the concepts in the course, and felt that the sessions had helped them learn more permanently and perform better on subsequent exams. 

Finally, we identified specific subareas of the certification exams in the various content areas in which SHU students have historically underperformed relative to their peers across the state. A living library of online, on-demand instructional videos and modules addressing these high difficulty content areas in Biology and Chemistry has been established, and content will be added as it is discovered/created.
